p: Drug repurposing is a quick and economical strategy to identify new therapeutic uses of approved drugs outside their original scope and is estimated to be the source of approximately 30% of newly approved drugs every year ( 4). An example of successful drug repurposing is the use of the chemotherapeutic agent azidothymidine as a therapy for HIV in the 1980s ( 4). Thus, the exploration of an efficient method for drug repurposing is necessary.
